hero.title: Designing Torus to Streamline Parametric Object Building
hero.subtitle: Working with 2 senior architects, I designed the core functionality for a modern browser-based architect platform to create parametric objects.

blocks.text: I worked with 2 senior architects to develop Torus, a browser-based CAD tool for creating parametric architectural objects. I tackled common pain points within Autodesk Revit by streamlining the UX of setting reference planes and assigning parameters. I conducted user research, designed wireframes, built a working MVP demo with AI assistance, and conducted user tests. With one iteration on UI, the final testing round showed a 100% completion rate. These results demonstrate that parametric processes can be intuited in under 5 minutes when built on modern, intuitive design principles.

bulletRows: Revit has awkward workflows are outdated, designed to mirror paper and pencil drafting.
Revit’s lack of prescriptive UX conflicts with modern practices that value strict logical processes.
The UI simply feels unintuitive. Key tools are hidden amongst many other tools with no logical order.

blocks.text:
Torus is born out of frustration with Autodesk Revit's family creation process. Revit is the dominant architecture tool and uses the term "family" to refer to reusable 3D components. Families are ideally built parametrically, meaning they are systematically generated with variables controlling aspects such as length and width. Creating families in Revit has a steep learning curve due to Revit's outdated UX.

Working alongside two senior architects, Matthew and Nicky, I set out to improve the UX of family creation. As a team, we settled on exploring this idea by designing and creating a separate browser-based family editor that can export to Revit. In my research of Revit, I identified 3 key frustrations:

bulletRows:
Revit families are difficult to create. - 

“Families are commonly used and not static...they can be tedious to set up.” - Danny

“It’s something I prefer not to do and takes too much of my time [because] it’s forcing us to build it like engineers.” - Dincer

Entire company roles are needed to help keep practices consistent. - 

“There are schools of thoughts, but people generally don’t follow them. Someone might say it works well when testing them in narrow cases, but I can tell they are not correctly build.” - Mark

Stock families often can't be customized for unique projects. - 

“Everything is made new because every project is different.” - Ihnil

blocks.text:
These frustrations were echoed in the 5 user interviews my team conducted during an exploratory phase. Interview candidates were all working architects with 4-10 years of experience.

As part of my Revit research, I also learned the fundamentals of creating parametric families. Creating a good parametric family is akin to writing good code. You need a mechanism to store variable data. You need to take that data as input and generate an output. You also want to generally avoid adding unnecessary elements. Just like in code, more cumbersome families mean more bloated projects and slower processing and rendering.

figure.caption: Screenshot of Autodesk Revit shows outdated and overwhelming UI.

blocks.text: Looking over the user research results, we decided early on to build Torus as a platform for constructing solely parametric families. Revit has a steep learning curve, as it is a master tool that encompasses several functionalities. Isolating our scope to just parametric family construction allowed us to optimize Torus towards a specific need.

I led the product design and consulted Matthew and Nicky on domain knowledge. To start wireframing the MVP, I drew inspiration from Figma and Onshape. I relied on the basic arch structure, with a panel on the left and right and a toolbox on top.

At the start, I made one key decision to deviate from Revit and include an Asset Tree for two primary reasons. The obvious reason was to allow the user to see all assets being added, which would encourage them to stay organized, knowing that each new asset was being recorded. The second reason was tied to a crucial feature that Matthew and Nicky pushed for. Torus would force objects like reference planes to have strictly enforced parent/child relationships. An Asset Tree would help users visualize the logic behind those relationships significantly better than the 3D environment alone can.

For the right-side panel, I decided to keep the Parameter Panel visible, communicating that parameters are fundamental to Torus' workflow.

figure.caption: UI of Torus MVP in the default 3D perspective view.

blocks.text: To determine which tools and features to prioritize, I consulted with Matthew and Nicky and learned to model several basic families in Revit to understand the parametric workflow. The core workflow involves 3 separate tools each with their own separate processes: placing reference planes (RPs act as variables in 3D space to prevent "hard-coded" values), drawing a magic line with the Aligned Dimensions tool, then using the label tool to parametricize the magic line. As a team, we decided that Torus’ UX differentiator will be to streamline this workflow with these three requirements.

items: Adding RPs - Force new RPs to be children created from pre-existing RPs.
Set Parameters - Smoothly weave this process into RP creation flow.
Explicitly Show Logic - Show geometry logic explicitly in the interface to allow better evaluation of the model.

sections.header: The UX of Adding Reference Planes

blocks.text:
As previously stated, Matthew and Nicky suggested early on that all user-generated RPs must be children of another RP. In contrast, Revit treats RPs as independent placed objects that are situationally constrained through other tools. As such, I decided that the default RP tool was not an "Add RP" tool, but a "Create RP by Offset" tool that creates a child RP from a designated parent RP, enforcing a formal hierarchical relationship among all RPs.

After several iterations, I decided on the final behavior of the OffsetRP tool.

items: The user chooses a Parent Plane.
The cursor transforms to a plane that is parallel to the Parent Plane with a Distance Indicator.
The user manually places a Child Plane by clicking in the workspace.

blocks.text: There was a design fork at Step 3. I could prompt the user to enter a distance and/or a parameter, and the child plane is generated automatically. I ultimately decided against this and opted for the user manually placing it with the cursor. I didn't want to completely strip away the pen-and-paper drafting mimicry that Revit relied on, as I was told verbatim, "most architects are still artists at heart, and not developers."

figure.caption: Offset RP tool creates a child RP.

blocks.text:
Next, I worked on streamlining the parameter-setting UX. In Revit, setting a single parameter is a minimum 2-step process with 2 different tools.

For Torus, I wanted to reduce it to 1 step and 1 feature by seamlessly integrating parameter setting with RP creation. I designed the offsetRP tool to have an automatic distance indicator. This distance indicator consisted of a dotted line connecting the RP to its parent and a value box. I designed the value box to turn into an input field where the user can type a parameter name and press Enter to confirm.

figure.caption: Setting a LENGTH parameter after creating a childRP.

blocks.text: Later in the MVP design process, I slightly expanded the scope and designed the OffsetEQRP tool to accommodate a common workflow. Since many families are symmetrical, a common Revit workflow is to create pairs of parallel RPs and then constrain them to be equidistant (EQ) from a center. To streamline this particularly common flow, I designed the OffsetEQRP tool to behave similarly to OffsetRP but automatically generate a mirrored RP. Both RPs would be added to an EQ group in the asset panel, and a parameter can be applied to the total distance between them.

figure.caption: Offset EQ RP tool creates a symmetrical RP pair.

blocks.text: Once these 3 features were designed, I took on the role of developer, testing coordinator, and UX interview conductor. I first built a working demo for the Torus MVP, mainly by generating prompts with Codex in VSC. While building the demo, I made the following UI changes:

items: Global Axis Colors - To accommodate more colors, I removed the pink and reduced the green.
Hover ID Indicators - Increase identification of RPs and global axis.
Resize RP Handles - Allow users to visually adjust the RP's appearance.

blocks.text:
Once the demo reached a testable stage, I reached out and found 6 participants who were architects or students. Their experiences with Revit ranged from a class to 10+ years. I ran 10-minute usability tests to see if users could add reference planes and set parameters. Before each session, I emphasized that this was an early-stage demo with limited capabilities.

4 participants completed both tasks. 2 participants completed both with minimal guidance. This was a major accomplishment and speaks to the design's relative intuitiveness. A few participants remarked that this would have been much more difficult in Revit.

I observed the following usability issues and made the following changes:

items.primary: All participants tried to hover over the tools, expecting tooltips to appear.
items.secondary: Add Tooltips - Add tooltips for offsetRP and offsetEQRP and increase the appearance speed.

items.primary: All participants first attempted to input numbers inside the distance indicator rather than the expected parameter name.
items.secondary: Refactor Distance Indicator - Create two input triggers that allow users to manipulate distance or set a parameter.

stamp.caption: Refactored distance input UI in Torus

items.primary: 3 participants pointed out that the parameter panel was not particularly clear.
items.secondary: Update Parameter Panel - Wrap name and value sets in a single container with an explicit "=".

stamp.caption: Updated parameter panel design in Torus

blocks.text: I tested this new iteration with 5 users, and the qualitative results significantly improved, with a 100% completion rate.

Now that the MVP can set up the parametric "bones" (as Matthew likes to call it), the next steps would be to enable users to create 2D geometry and then turn it into 3D geometry. I've already initiated the design process to streamline another infamous Revit function: locking 2D geometry to RPs. Also, a user behavior question emerged during testing. Less experienced users, particularly students, leaned more on the 3D perspective view. In contrast, more experienced users valued the 2D views that enable the parametric workflow.

items.text: Build and test the clasp system for locking 2D geometry to reference planes.

stamp.caption: Clasp system concept for locking 2D geometry to reference planes

items.text: Research how experience-level impacts workflow preferences.

blocks.text: Torus was one of the most rewarding and challenging projects I've worked on, requiring hands-on involvement across every stage of product development, from research and wireframing to agile development and usability testing. This project demonstrated that even deeply technical, legacy workflows can support intuitive, modern UX when designed with clear structure and intention. Ultimately, the successful feedback results of the initial MVP showed that a modern parametric CAD tool can be intuitively understood and used in under 5 minutes. I'm grateful to Matthew and Nicky for sharing their domain expertise and for their close collaboration throughout the project.
